BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The large quantity of fresh snow and the deep wind slabs can be released naturally in all aspects. From starting zones at higher altitudes natural avalanches, capable of reaching a long way in some cases, must be expected.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
Over a wide area 15 to 40 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, has fallen since Friday above approximately 2000 m.
As the snowfall becomes more intense numerous avalanches are possible, but they can be very large in isolated cases. The large quantity of fresh snow and the deep wind slabs can be released naturally in all aspects. The avalanches can occur again, even in paths where avalanches have already been released.
The fresh and somewhat older wind slabs can be released by a single winter sport participant in all aspects at intermediate and high altitudes. Remotely triggered avalanches are possible. The avalanche prone locations are widespread and are barely recognisable because of the poor visibility.
It is inadvisable to engage in snow sport activities outside marked and open pistes.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
Sunday: Over a wide area 60 to 100 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, will fall above approximately 2000 m.
The new snow is bonding poorly with the old snowpack in many places. Towards its base, the snowpack is unstable; its surface consists of loosely bonded snow.
The snowpack will become gradually prone to triggering.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: Monday: The new snow of the weekend remains for the foreseeable future prone to triggering. Numerous avalanches are to be expected, even very large ones in isolated cases.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: From starting zones at higher altitudes natural avalanches, capable of reaching the valleys, must be expected more frequently. Without question, it is inadvisable to engage in snow sport activities outside marked and open pistes.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
As a consequence of, heavy snowfall and the occasionally strong southeasterly wind, a very critical avalanche situation will develop on Sunday. In localities where more snow falls danger level 5 (very high) may be reached in the course of the day.
Many large and, in isolated cases, very large natural avalanches are possible, also in all aspects on steep slopes.
In addition the danger of powder avalanches will increase as the day progresses. Exposed transportation routes and exposed settlements can be endangered in some localities.
The avalanches can occur again, even in paths where avalanches have already been released.
Weak layers exist in the bottom section of the old snowpack on northwest, north and east facing slopes. Weak layers near the ground can be released by individual winter sport participants. Remotely triggered avalanches are possible. The avalanche prone locations are widespread barely recognisable because of the poor visibility.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
Over a wide area over a wide area 80 to 150 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, will fall until Sunday above approximately 1500 m.
60 to 100 cm of snow fell in the last seven days above approximately 2000 m. The southeasterly wind will transport the new snow significantly. A lot of snow is lying at intermediate and high altitudes. The weather was cloudy.
Towards its base, the snowpack is unfavourably layered; its surface consists of faceted crystals. Numerous medium-sized and, in isolated cases, large dry and wet avalanches have been released in the last two days.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: The avalanche danger will not decrease for the time being. The new snow of the weekend remains for the foreseeable future prone to triggering. The conditions are precarious for snow sport activities outside marked and open pistes.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The large quantity of fresh snow and the deep wind slabs can be released naturally in all aspects. From starting zones at higher altitudes natural avalanches, capable of reaching the valleys, must be expected more frequently.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
Over a wide area 60 to 90 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, has fallen since Friday above approximately 2000 m.
As the snowfall becomes more intense numerous avalanches are possible, but they can be very large in some cases. In addition the danger of powder avalanches will increase in the afternoon. The avalanches can occur again, even in paths where avalanches have already been released.

The fresh and somewhat older wind slabs can be released by a single winter sport participant in all aspects in all altitude zones. Remotely triggered avalanches are possible. The avalanche prone locations are widespread and are barely recognisable because of the poor visibility.
Without question, it is inadvisable to engage in snow sport activities outside marked and open pistes.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: Sunday: Over a wide area 70 to 80 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, will fall above approximately 2000 m. The new snow is poorly bonded with the old snowpack in many places. Towards its base, the snowpack is unfavourably layered; its surface consists of faceted crystals. The snowpack will become gradually prone to triggering. As a consequence of snowfall and the occasionally strong southerly wind, the snow drift accumulations have increased in size.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: Monday: The new snow of the weekend remains for the foreseeable future prone to triggering. Numerous avalanches are to be expected, even very large ones in isolated cases.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The avalanche danger will increase during the day. The large quantity of fresh snow and the deep wind slabs can be released naturally in all aspects. From starting zones at higher altitudes natural avalanches, capable of reaching a long way in some cases, must be expected.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
15 to 25 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, has fallen since yesterday above approximately 2000 m. As the snowfall becomes more intense numerous avalanches are possible from the late morning, but they can be very large in isolated cases. The large quantity of fresh snow and the deep wind slabs can be released naturally in all aspects. In the regions exposed to heavier precipitation the avalanche danger will increase more quickly.
The fresh and somewhat older wind slabs can be released by a single winter sport participant in all aspects at intermediate and high altitudes. Remotely triggered avalanches are possible. The avalanche prone locations are widespread and are barely recognisable because of the poor visibility.
It is inadvisable to engage in snow sport activities outside marked and open pistes.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
Sunday: Over a wide area 40 to 80 cm of snow, and up to 90 cm in some localities, will fall above approximately 2000 m.
The new snow is poorly bonded with the old snowpack in many places.
As a consequence of the moderate to strong southeasterly wind, fresh snow drift accumulations will form in the course of the day. The snowpack will become gradually prone to triggering.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: Monday: The new snow of the weekend remains for the foreseeable future prone to triggering. Numerous avalanches are to be expected, even very large ones in isolated cases.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The avalanche danger will increase during the day. The large quantity of fresh snow and the deep wind slabs can be released naturally in all aspects. From starting zones at higher altitudes natural avalanches, capable of reaching a long way in some cases, must be expected.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
15 to 25 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, has fallen since yesterday above approximately 2000 m. As the snowfall becomes more intense numerous avalanches are possible from the late morning, but they can be very large in isolated cases. The large quantity of fresh snow and the deep wind slabs can be released naturally in all aspects. In the regions exposed to heavier precipitation the avalanche danger will increase more quickly.
The fresh and somewhat older wind slabs can be released by a single winter sport participant in all aspects at intermediate and high altitudes. Remotely triggered avalanches are possible. The avalanche prone locations are widespread and are barely recognisable because of the poor visibility.
It is inadvisable to engage in snow sport activities outside marked and open pistes.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
Sunday: Over a wide area 40 to 80 cm of snow, and up to 90 cm in some localities, will fall above approximately 2000 m.
The new snow is poorly bonded with the old snowpack in many places.
As a consequence of the moderate to strong southeasterly wind, fresh snow drift accumulations will form in the course of the day. The snowpack will become gradually prone to triggering.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: Monday: The new snow of the weekend remains for the foreseeable future prone to triggering. Numerous avalanches are to be expected, even very large ones in isolated cases.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: From starting zones at higher altitudes natural avalanches, capable of reaching a long way, must be expected in many places. It is inadvisable to engage in snow sport activities outside marked and open pistes.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
As a consequence of, heavy snowfall the moderate to strong southeasterly wind, an unfavourable avalanche situation will develop. Numerous large and, in isolated cases, very large natural avalanches are possible, also in all aspects on steep slopes. In localities where more than 100 cm of snow falls the danger will increase more quickly.
In addition the danger of powder avalanches will increase as the day progresses. Exposed transportation routes and exposed settlements can be endangered occasionally.
Weak layers exist in the bottom section of the old snowpack on northwest, north and east facing slopes. Weak layers near the ground can be released by individual winter sport participants. Remotely triggered avalanches are possible. The avalanche prone locations are widespread barely recognisable because of the poor visibility.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
Over a wide area over a wide area 70 to 130 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, will fall until Sunday above approximately 1500 m.
40 to 60 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, fell in the last seven days above approximately 2000 m. The southeasterly wind will transport the new snow. A lot of snow is lying at intermediate and high altitudes. The weather was cloudy.
Towards its base, the snowpack is unfavourably layered; its surface consists of faceted crystals. Stability tests and field observations confirm a precarious avalanche situation.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: The avalanche danger will not decrease for the time being. The new snow of the weekend remains for the foreseeable future prone to triggering. The conditions are precarious for snow sport activities outside marked and open pistes.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The fresh snow and the wind slabs represent the main danger. The avalanche danger will increase during the day.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
As a consequence of the moderate to strong southeasterly wind, snow drift accumulations will form. These can be released by a single winter sport participant in all aspects and generally above the tree line.
The wind slabs are to be found especially adjacent to ridgelines and in gullies and bowls.
Whumpfing sounds and the formation of shooting cracks when stepping on the snowpack and natural avalanches serve as an alarm sign.

As a consequence of new snow and wind avalanches are to be expected, even large ones in isolated cases. The snowpack will be prone to triggering in particular in extremely steep terrain. The current avalanche situation calls for extensive experience in the assessment of avalanche danger and careful route selection.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
15 to 30 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, will fall. The moderate wind will transport the new snow significantly.
A lot of snow is lying at intermediate and high altitudes.
Over a wide area new snow and wind slabs are lying on the soft surface of an old snowpack. Towards its base, the snowpack is unfavourably layered and has a loosely bonded surface.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: Monday: The new snow of the weekend remains for the foreseeable future prone to triggering. The avalanche danger will not decrease for the time being.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The fresh snow and the wind slabs represent the main danger. The avalanche danger will increase during the day.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
As a consequence of the moderate to strong southeasterly wind, snow drift accumulations will form. These can be released by a single winter sport participant in all aspects and generally above the tree line.
The wind slabs are to be found especially adjacent to ridgelines and in gullies and bowls.
Whumpfing sounds and the formation of shooting cracks when stepping on the snowpack and natural avalanches serve as an alarm sign.

As a consequence of new snow and wind avalanches are to be expected, even large ones in isolated cases. The snowpack will be prone to triggering in particular in extremely steep terrain. The current avalanche situation calls for extensive experience in the assessment of avalanche danger and careful route selection.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
15 to 30 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, will fall. The moderate wind will transport the new snow significantly.
A lot of snow is lying at intermediate and high altitudes.
Over a wide area new snow and wind slabs are lying on the soft surface of an old snowpack. Towards its base, the snowpack is unfavourably layered and has a loosely bonded surface.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: Monday: The new snow of the weekend remains for the foreseeable future prone to triggering. The avalanche danger will not decrease for the time being.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Weakly bonded old snow on northwest, north and east facing slopes. Backcountry touring calls for defensive route selection.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
As a consequence of, heavy snowfall the moderate to strong southeasterly wind, an unfavourable avalanche situation will develop. Medium-sized and, in many cases, large natural avalanches are possible.
In particular from starting zones at higher altitudes large natural avalanches, capable of reaching a long way in some cases, must be expected. In addition the danger of powder avalanches will increase as the day progresses.
Weak layers exist in the bottom section of the old snowpack on northwest, north and east facing slopes. Weak layers near the ground can be released by individual winter sport participants. Remotely triggered avalanches are possible. The avalanche prone locations are widespread barely recognisable because of the poor visibility. In particular transitions from a shallow to a deep snowpack are especially dangerous.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
Over a wide area over a wide area 40 to 80 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, will fall until Sunday above approximately 1500 m.
30 to 50 cm of snow fell in the last seven days above approximately 2000 m. The southeasterly wind will transport the new snow. The weather was cloudy.
Towards its base, the snowpack is unfavourably layered; its surface consists of faceted crystals. Stability tests and field observations confirm a precarious avalanche situation.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: Monday: Gradual increase in danger of dry avalanches as a consequence of the moderate to strong northwesterly wind.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: New snow and wind slabs in high Alpine regions. In particular in the regions exposed to heavier precipitation the wind slabs will increase in size additionally. Gliding avalanches can be released at any time of day or night.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: The fresh snow and the large wind slabs represent the main danger. As a consequence of the snowfall slab avalanches are possible, even large ones in isolated cases.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: The snowpack will be unstable in particular on steep northeast, north and northwest facing slopes. In some cases the wind slabs have bonded still only poorly with the old snowpack.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Wet and gliding snow require caution. Fresh wind slabs at high altitude.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
Wet loose snow avalanches are to be expected, even medium-sized ones. In addition an appreciable danger of gliding avalanches exists, in particular on steep slopes below approximately 2400 m. Areas with glide cracks are to be avoided. These can reach dangerously large size.

The fresh wind slabs can be released by a single winter sport participant in particular on steep shady slopes above approximately 2500 m. This applies especially adjacent to ridgelines. In some cases avalanches are medium-sized. The number and size of avalanche prone locations will increase with altitude.

Avalanches can in isolated cases be triggered in the old snowpack. Avalanche prone locations are to be found in particular on very steep shady slopes.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: In some regions 5 to 10 cm of snow fell on Friday above approximately 2000 m. Little snow will fall on Saturday in some localities. The snowpack will be moist below approximately 2400 m. In some places new snow and wind slabs are lying on a weakly bonded old snowpack. In some regions up to 10 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, fell on Friday above approximately 2000 m. Some snow will fall until Monday in some localities. The snowpack will be moist below approximately 2400 m. In some places new snow and wind slabs are lying on a weakly bonded old snowpack. The fresh and somewhat older wind slabs are lying on soft layers especially on steep shady slopes at high altitude.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: Wind and new snow above approximately 1400 m. In some localities up to 20 cm of snow will fall.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights:
The weather conditions gave rise to softening of the snowpack.
Over a wide area precipitation.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
In all aspects large and, in isolated cases, very large moist and wet avalanches are possible. In steep rocky terrain and adjacent to ridgelines more moist and wet snow slides are possible. Gliding avalanches can be released at any time of day or night. Areas with glide cracks are to be avoided.
Even single winter sport participants can release avalanches. Backcountry touring calls for experience in the assessment of avalanche danger and careful route selection.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
A lot of snow is lying at intermediate and high altitudes.
The snowpack remains generally moist. Weak layers exist in the snowpack.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: Unexpected weather pattern: Some snow will fall over a wide area.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Fresh wind slabs represent the main danger. Gliding snow requires caution.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
The fresh and somewhat older wind slabs can be released even by a single winter sport participant in particular on steep shady slopes above approximately 2400 m. The number and size of avalanche prone locations will increase with altitude. Weak layers in the old snowpack can still be released in very isolated cases by individual winter sport participants. Avalanche prone locations are to be found in particular on very steep west, north and east facing slopes above approximately 2600 m. Avalanche prone locations are to be found in particular on very steep north facing slopes in all altitude zones between approximately 2100 and 2300 m. Avalanches can in isolated cases penetrate deep layers and reach large size.

More frequent wet loose snow avalanches are to be expected, even medium-sized ones. In addition an appreciable danger of gliding avalanches exists, especially on grassy slopes below approximately 2600 m, as well as on steep shady slopes below approximately 2400 m.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
In some regions up to 30 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, will fall until Monday above approximately 1500 m. The snowpack will be moist below approximately 2400 m. The surface of the snowpack will soften quickly.

As a consequence of new snow and strong wind the wind slabs will increase in size. Fresh and somewhat older wind slabs are lying on soft layers in particular on shady slopes. They are in some cases prone to triggering. This applies above approximately 2600 m.
Isolated avalanche prone weak layers exist deeper in the snowpack in particular on steep east, north and west facing slopes. In very isolated cases new snow and wind slabs are lying on a weakly bonded old snowpack.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: Fresh wind slabs require caution. Gliding avalanches and moist snow slides require caution.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Fresh wind slabs represent the main danger. Gliding snow requires caution.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
The fresh and somewhat older wind slabs can be released even by a single winter sport participant in particular on steep shady slopes above approximately 2400 m. The number and size of avalanche prone locations will increase with altitude. Weak layers in the old snowpack can still be released in very isolated cases by individual winter sport participants. Avalanche prone locations are to be found in particular on very steep west, north and east facing slopes above approximately 2600 m. Avalanche prone locations are to be found in particular on very steep north facing slopes in all altitude zones between approximately 2100 and 2300 m. Avalanches can in isolated cases penetrate deep layers and reach large size.

More frequent wet loose snow avalanches are to be expected, even medium-sized ones. In addition an appreciable danger of gliding avalanches exists, especially on grassy slopes below approximately 2600 m, as well as on steep shady slopes below approximately 2400 m.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
In some regions up to 30 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, will fall until Monday above approximately 1500 m. The snowpack will be moist below approximately 2400 m. The surface of the snowpack will soften quickly.

As a consequence of new snow and strong wind the wind slabs will increase in size. Fresh and somewhat older wind slabs are lying on soft layers in particular on shady slopes. They are in some cases prone to triggering. This applies above approximately 2600 m.
Isolated avalanche prone weak layers exist deeper in the snowpack in particular on steep east, north and west facing slopes. In very isolated cases new snow and wind slabs are lying on a weakly bonded old snowpack.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: Fresh wind slabs require caution. Gliding avalanches and moist snow slides require caution.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights:
The weather conditions gave rise to softening of the snowpack.
Over a wide area precipitation.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: In all aspects large and, in isolated cases, very large moist and wet avalanches are possible. Gliding avalanches can also occur at any time. Single winter sport participants can release avalanches as before.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
In particular in the north a lot of snow is lying at intermediate and high altitudes.
The snowpack remains generally moist.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: Unexpected weather pattern: Some snow will fall over a wide area.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The snowpack will be gradually wet all the way through.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: Outgoing longwave radiation during the night will be barely evident. The surface of the snowpack is not frozen and will already be soft in the early morning. Already in the early morning, individual, then as a consequence of the rain more, and in some cases even medium-sized, wet and gliding avalanches are possible.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: The avalanche prone locations are to be found in particular on steep grassy slopes below approximately 2000 m. As a consequence of high temperatures and rain the snowpack could settle hardly at all.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Wet and gliding snow require caution. Fresh wind slabs at high altitude.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
More frequent wet loose snow avalanches are to be expected, even medium-sized ones. In addition an appreciable danger of gliding avalanches exists, in particular on steep sunny slopes below approximately 2600 m, as well as on steep shady slopes below approximately 2400 m.

The fresh wind slabs can be released by a single winter sport participant in isolated cases in particular on very steep shady slopes above approximately 2600 m. This applies especially adjacent to ridgelines. In some cases avalanches are medium-sized. The number and size of avalanche prone locations will increase with altitude.

Avalanches can in very isolated cases be triggered in the old snowpack. Avalanche prone locations are to be found in particular on very steep east and west facing slopes above approximately 2600 m. Avalanche prone locations are to be found also on very steep north facing slopes between approximately 2100 and 2300 m.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
Some snow will fall until Monday in particular in the south.
The snowpack will be wet all the way through below approximately 2200 m. The snowpack will be moist below approximately 2400 m. The surface of the snowpack will soften quickly.

Fresh and somewhat older wind slabs are lying on soft layers in particular on shady slopes. This applies above approximately 2600 m. In very isolated cases new snow and wind slabs are lying on a weakly bonded old snowpack.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: Wet and gliding avalanches are the main danger.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Wet and gliding snow require caution. Fresh wind slabs at high altitude.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
More frequent wet loose snow avalanches are to be expected, even medium-sized ones. In addition an appreciable danger of gliding avalanches exists, in particular on steep sunny slopes below approximately 2600 m, as well as on steep shady slopes below approximately 2400 m. These can reach dangerously large size.

The fresh wind slabs can be released by a single winter sport participant in isolated cases in particular on very steep shady slopes above approximately 2600 m. This applies especially adjacent to ridgelines. In some cases avalanches are medium-sized. The number and size of avalanche prone locations will increase with altitude.

Avalanches can in very isolated cases be triggered in the old snowpack. Avalanche prone locations are to be found in particular on very steep east and west facing slopes above approximately 2600 m. Avalanche prone locations are to be found also on very steep north facing slopes between approximately 2100 and 2300 m.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
Some snow will fall until Monday in particular in the south.
The snowpack will be wet all the way through below approximately 2200 m. The snowpack will be moist below approximately 2400 m. The surface of the snowpack will soften quickly.

Fresh and somewhat older wind slabs are lying on soft layers in particular on shady slopes. This applies above approximately 2600 m. In very isolated cases new snow and wind slabs are lying on a weakly bonded old snowpack.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: Wet and gliding avalanches are the main danger.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The snowpack will be gradually wet all the way through.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: The surface of the snowpack is not frozen and will already be soft in the early morning.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: The avalanche prone locations are to be found in particular on steep grassy slopes below approximately 2000 m. As a consequence of high temperatures and rain the snowpack could settle hardly at all.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Wind slabs require caution. In addition individual gliding avalanches and moist snow slides are to be expected.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
Wind slabs can be released by a single winter sport participant in isolated cases in particular on steep shady slopes at high altitude. Mostly avalanches are only small.

On steep grassy slopes mostly small gliding avalanches and moist snow slides are possible.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
Some snow will fall in particular in the north. The wind slabs are in isolated cases prone to triggering.

The snowpack will be moist below approximately 2400 m. At low altitude hardly any snow is lying.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: Moist loose snow slides require caution.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: New snow and wind slabs above approximately 1500 m.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: Mostly small avalanches are possible. This applies especially on steep slopes especially above approximately 1600 m, and adjacent to ridgelines and in gullies and bowls.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: The new snow and wind slabs of the last few days represent the main danger. Below approximately 1600 m a little snow is lying. At high altitude the avalanche danger is a little higher.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Wind slabs require caution. In addition individual gliding avalanches and moist snow slides are to be expected.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
Wind slabs can be released by a single winter sport participant in isolated cases in particular on steep shady slopes at high altitude. Mostly avalanches are only small.

On steep grassy slopes mostly small gliding avalanches and moist snow slides are possible.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
Some snow will fall in particular in the north. The wind slabs are in isolated cases prone to triggering.

The snowpack will be moist below approximately 2400 m. At low altitude hardly any snow is lying.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: Moist loose snow slides require caution.
